Award.AwardTitle: Biomedical Innovations Using Implementation-Aware Agile Sensing and Signal Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Title: Biomedical Innovations Using Implementation-Aware <br/> Agile Sensing and Signal Processing<br/>Abstract:<br/>Medical condition diagnosis is heavily based on sensor measurements <br/>and their processing. These measurements correspond to waveforms <br/>that propagate over the complex body environment and are transformed <br/>linearly or nonlinearly according to the characteristic environment properties. <br/>However, the medical community does not fully exploit the potentials of <br/>advanced processing matched to nonlinear structures or modern sensor <br/>technologies such as waveform agility that leads to significant estimation<br/>performance improvements. This research exploits advanced <br/>implementation-aware sensing and processing techniques to improve <br/>medical diagnosis by: (a) efficient processing using compressed sensing <br/>and nonlinear time-varying spectral methods; (b) estimation of environment <br/>descriptors and disease state parameters combined with waveform-agile<br/>sensing; and (c) mapping estimation and waveform-agile sensing algorithms <br/>onto field-programmable gate arrays. This framework brings revolutionary <br/>advances in diagnosing, treating, and tracking disease states that are <br/>otherwise difficult to obtain as advanced processing techniques are either <br/>not available or too costly. The investigators also design on-line software <br/>toolboxes with sensing experiments for use in outreach programs to recruit <br/>and retain freshmen and underrepresented student populations.<br/><br/>The research integrates advanced signal processing, stochastic Bayesian <br/>estimation, and waveform-agile sensing with implementation-aware <br/>algorithms to improve estimation of disease states. The investigators study<br/>time-frequency techniques matched to nonlinear structures to process biomedical <br/>data. Compressive sensing methodologies are developed that reduce the<br/>number of required measurements and allow for alternative computational <br/>algorithms. Mathematical descriptors are designed to model disease states using<br/>time-varying transfer functions. Sequential Bayesian techniques and waveform <br/>adaptation are used to estimate information. Algorithm reconstruction procedures <br/>are developed that trade high performance for reduced implementation cost. <br/>Finally, the investigators design algorithms cognizant of complexity and memory requirements.<br/>
